Ekhe a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology, Nagpur, 440010, India Department of Chemistry Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology Nagpur 440010 India b Environmental Materials Division, CSIR-National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur, 440020, India Environmental Materials Division CSIR-National Environmental Engineering Research Institute Nagpur 440020 India c Department of Chemical Engineering, Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology, Nagpur, 440010, India Department of Chemical Engineering Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology Nagpur 440010 India ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A superacidic mesoporous catalyst WOX/RHS-MCM-41 was synthesized using high purity biogenic silica extracted from an agro-waste, rice husk ash. Catalyst acidity was enhanced by dispersion of surface WOX groups on mesoporous support and was used for methanolysis of soybean oil and free fatty acid. Catalyst activity was found to depend upon the structure of WOX species formed over catalyst surface. Characterization with XRD, SEM, TEM, UV–vis DRS, Raman spectroscopy and acidity determination revealed that formation of highly dispersed amorphous polyoxotungstate phase on the catalyst surface developed with a specific tungsten loading and originated strong acidic sites showing high activity. Kinetic analysis revealed that pseudo-first order kinetics was followed up to the optimum reaction time with an activation energy 42.7kJmol−1. Catalyst showed high activity giving ∼90% FAME yield and reusability for multiple cycles without regeneration. The high catalytic activity was retained even in presence of free fatty acid also. Keywords Polyoxotungstate Mesoporous catalyst Rice husk silica Methanolysis Vegetable oil 1 Introduction Limited fossil fuel reserves and concern for global climate change due to incremental green house gas (GHG) emission has encouraged research towards the use of renewable resources with potential to meet the increasing energy demand. Biodiesel is a renewable and biodegradable fuel [1] producing less toxic combustion profile in terms of hydrocarbons, SOX and reduces 50% GHG addition compared to petro-diesel thus may be considered as a “green fuel” [2,3]. Its applicability in existing diesel engine makes it the most attractive alternative to petro-diesel. Additional superiority in lubricity characteristics, flash point and cetane number over petroleum diesel results longer engine life [4]. Biodiesel is commercially produced from renewable triglyceride (TG) feedstocks like soybean, sunflower, rapeseed, palm oil, etc. via transesterification of TGs with short chain alcohol typically methanol or ethanol. Methanol is preferred as it can be produced easily from syngas [5]. However; high price for TG feedstocks weakens the process economy [6]. Industrial biodiesel production is carried out using homogeneous basic catalyst which demands high quality TG feedstock with free fatty acids (FFAs)<0.5% and moisture free, because of saponification and hydrolysis issues [6–8]. Mineral acids although can work with low grade TG feedstocks but gives slow reaction and require special industrial equipments due to high corrosivity [9,10]. Thus heterogeneous acids may serve an alternative and sustainable solution as they are recyclable, impart less impurity to products and enable to run a continuous production process [11,12]. Several studies on development of solid acid catalysts were reported using sulfated, tungstated zirconia [1,13] alkaline metal supported zirconia [14], sulfonated saccharides [15–18], nafion, amberlyst resins and related composites [1,19,20], organosulfonic acid functionalized mesoporous silica [21–23] etc. Some resins were found active due to associated high acidic site density; but thermal stability issue impairs their use in high temperature. Some highly acidic microporous zeolites (e.g. H-β, ETS-10 (H)) were also tried but not found effective due to the internal mass transfer limitation through micropores [1,24]. Tungstated zirconia, as a highly efficient solid acid catalyst was first introduced by Hino and Arata [25]. The catalyst’s activity largely depends upon the structure and surface density of WOX species and ZrO2 surface area. Some research groups reported the utilizaltion of direct tungstated zirconia for biodiesel production from dark oil [26], used VOs [27] (vegetable oils) and WCO (waste cooking oil) [28]. MCM-41 is a well explored mesoporous material with high specific surface area, well structured larger pores and significant stability. Only few studies were reported employing MCM-41 silica supported solid acid catalyst for transesterification of VOs. A FAME yield of 82% was obtained in 2.5h with WOX supported Zr-MCM-41 catalyst carrying the reaction at 200°C [2]. Whereas on Zr(SO4)2 impregnation over pure silica MCM-41 produced 73% FAEE (Fatty Acid Ethyl Ester) yield with sunflower oil within a reaction time of 6h at 200°C [6]. All the cases involved catalysts synthesized with very expensive silica precursor like tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) and reactions were carried out at higher temperature. In current study, we synthesized dispersed WOX functionalized mesoporous catalyst using RHS-MCM-41 (rice husk silica-MCM-41) molecular sieve prepared with RHS, very low cost biogenic silica. Al incorporation was for enhancing hydrothermal stability of the support as well as creating acidic sites which further increased on dispersion of WOX phase. Tungsten incorporation was varied from 5 to 20wt.% to optimize catalyst activity. We used this catalyst for transesterification of soybean oil with simultaneous esterification of 10wt.% oleic acid (as FFA) added externally to simulate the low grade TGs feedstocks. Unlike the earlier studies with pure silica MCM-41 catalysts [2,6], reactions were carried out at much lower temperature (140°C). Catalyst characterizations along with the reaction performance enabled us to investigate the structure activity relationship of this WOX/RHS-MCM-41 catalyst. Response surface methodology (RSM) was applied to get the optimum reaction condition for highest FAME yield. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis RHA obtained from local agro industry (Yash Agro, Nagpur, India) was used for silica extraction by alkali digestion method [29]. Hydrothermal synthesis of RHS-MCM-41 with Si/Al ratio 30 was carried out with RHS following synthesis methods of Ryoo et al. [30] and Lindlar et al. [31] with minor modifications. In a typical synthesis procedure RHS was dissolved in water with NaOH under constant stirring at 80–90°C to obtain a clear solution whereas in referred methods sodium silicate solution or Ludox HS40 (as purchased) were used as silica precursor. Separately aluminium solution and template solution were prepared by dissolving Al2(SO4)3,16H2O (Merck, Emparta) and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (Sigma-Aldrich) in deionized water with constant stirring. The final gel was prepared by very slow addition of silicate and aluminium solution simultaneously to template solution under vigorous stirring at RT (room temperature). Final gel composition was SiO2:0.126 CTAB: x Al2O3:0.277 Na2O: 0.019 NH3: 33.7 H2O (x varies with Si/Al ratio). After vigorous stirring for 1h, the resultant gel mixture was transferred to a teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The sealed autoclave was kept in hot air oven at 100°C for 96h. After each 24h of aging period, the reaction mixture was cooled to RT and pH adjusted to 11±0.1 using 6N H2SO4. This process of adjusting pH was repeated thrice. Finally the white precipitate, obtained after 96h aging was filtered, washed with EtOH followed by deionized water several times and dried overnight at 80°C in hot air oven. Template was removed from RHS-MCM-41 via calcination of the dried material at 540°C for 6h under ultra high pure (UHP) air atmosphere with a heating rate of 2°C/min. The synthesized RHS-MCM-41 was treated with 1mol/L (NH4)2SO4 solution followed by calcination at 540°C for 4h to get protonated form of RHS-MCM-41. This material was finally functionalized with WOX using ammonium metatungstate (Sigma-Aldrich) via incipient wetness impregnation method [32] and the final catalyst was obtained by calcination of the dried materials at 540°C for 4h under UHP air atmosphere [33]. 2.2 Materials characterization Small angle and wide angle X-ray powder diffraction patterns of catalysts were obtained from Bruker AXS-D8 advance and Rigaku MiniFlex300 respectively. UV–visible diffused reflectance spectra (UV-vis-DRS) were recorded with JASCO made spectrophotometer (model V-670). Surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of all catalysts were measured using nitrogen adsorption-desorption BET and BJH method in ASAP-2020 porosimeter (Micromeritics). Surface morphology and structure of catalysts were observed in SEM (model JSM-7600F). Catalysts’ elemental compositions and surface mapping were performed by EDS unit (BRUKER XFlash 6/30) attached to SEM. The TEM micrographs were obtained from PHILIPS CM200 electron microscope. Raman spectroscopic analysis was performed with HORIBA make LabRAM HR Evolution spectrophotometer system with a Peltier cooled CCD detector and Olympus BX-41 microscope. Total acidic sites quantification was performed using non-aqueous potentiometric titration method [34]. The detail EDS spectra and elemental mapping of different studied catalysts are presented in Figs. S7–S11 and corresponding elemental composition is provided in Table S5 (SI). Further details on material characterization are given in supporting information (SI). 2.3 Transesterification reaction Transesterification of soybean oil with methanol was carried out in SS316 reactor of 60mL capacity equipped with a heating and stirring system. The reaction mixture was stirred at 800rpm to reduce mass transfer limitation in the three phase system. Optimization of reaction parameters was performed using RSM for maximum FAME yield. A twenty set of experiments were carried out. The details of experimental design are provided in Section 2 (SI). After reaction completion, catalyst was separated by centrifugation at 10,000rpm for 5min followed by phase separation. The upper biodiesel phase was analyzed for TG conversion and FAME yield using gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-14B) coupled with FID detector. Further details on GC quantification are provided in Section 3 (SI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization In small angle X-Ray diffractogram (Fig. 1 ), diffractions from (100), (110) and (200) crystal planes were observed in 2θ range 2–5° which are similar to that by hexagonal lattice geometry of typical MCM-41 material. Whereas, in wide angle diffraction (Fig. 2 ), a hump corresponding to amorphous aluminosilicate phase was observed in 2θ range ∼20–25°. Hexagonal unit cell parameter (a 0) obtained using the formula a 0 =2d 100/√3 was found to be 44.0Å for pure RHS-MCM-41 which on incorporation of W results in slight lowering to 43.3Å (W-20). With increasing W loading diffraction peak intensity from (100) plane was also observed to reduce with little peak widening which may be due to reduced hexagonal structural order [35]. The corresponding crystallographic parameters are summarized in Table 1 . All the calcined mesoporous catalysts possess well defined pore structure formed via condensation of silanol groups. As evidenced from wide angle XRD analysis, the amorphous WOX phase formed over the mesoporous RHS-MCM-41 support finally converted to well structured orthorhombic WO3 phase on increasing W content up to 20wt.%. Fig. 2 clearly shows that WOX phase transformation from amorphous to crystalline is very prominent on shifting from W-15 to W-20. The crystallite size of WO3 phase in W-20 catalyst was calculated using Scherrer’s equation and average crystallite size was found to be 38.4nm whereas in W-15 no prominent diffraction peak is observable. The corresponding calculations of average crystallite size with different crystallographic parameters obtained in XRD measurement are included in Table S1 (SI). Crystalline WO3 phase formation in W-20 catalyst resulted, lowering in acidic strength, which was observed in acidity estimation. Whereas the W-15 catalyst with amorphous WOX phase exhibits strongest acidic sites compared to others in the studied series [36]. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption study of all catalysts generated hysteresis loops that can be categorized as type IV isotherm characteristics of mesoporous material [37]. The isotherms of different studied catalysts presented in Fig. 3 consist of three well defined stages. The initial stage of slow N2 uptake at lower P/P0 may be attributed to monolayer and multilayer adsorption by catalyst pore walls. The next stage is a sharp steep at intermediate P/P0 which indicates the capillary condensation process inside the mesopores while the final stage of adsorption corresponding to the plateau portion at higher P/P0. This part of isotherm may be associated with multilayer adsorption by catalysts external surface [35,38]. The sharpness and height of the capillary condensation stage indicates the uniformity in pore diameter. Conversely, deviation from sharpness or absence of well defined pore filling step reveals heterogeneity in pore size distribution. Capillary condensation is essentially accompanied by hysteresis. The shape of hysteresis loop depends upon the pore structure and pore diameter of the material investigated. Adsorption and desorption process follows the reversible pathway on the stage of monolayer and multilayer adsorption region. But in capillary condensation region they do not follow the reversible pathway forming a hysteresis loop. But the width of the loop reduces along with reduction of pore diameter and vanishes at a critical pore diameter. It was also observed that two dimensional porous systems with sufficiently long capillaries of critical diameters exhibit narrower hysteresis loop [39–41]. Here in the studied series of catalyst hysteresis loops were found to be narrow with reduction in width as tungsten incorporation increased. The relative values of BET surface area, BJH pore diameter and pore volume are summarized in Table 1. The pure RHS-MCM-41 was having a surface area of 988m2 g−1, which gradually dropped down to 828m2 g−1 on W incorporation to (20wt.%), which may be due to the blockage of pores by increasing tungsten deposition. Hence tungsten loading, although not significantly altered the pore size distribution but due to blockage of pores the relative surface area, pore volume and average pore diameter reduced. Surface morphological features like particle size, shape and their structural homogeneity before and after tungsten impregnation was observed with SEM (Fig. 4 A & B respectively). The particles were regular spherical shaped, although some degree of agglomeration occurred therein. The average particle dimension of RHS-MCM-41 was found to be around 1–2μm. Tungsten incorporation in different extent leaves no significant difference in particle morphology. The TEM micrographs of pure RHS-MCM-41 and after tungsten incorporation (20%) are presented in Fig. 4C & D respectively. All the catalysts presented well-defined hexagonal arrangement with uniform pore structure and well ordered channels. Good crystallinity with little amorphous zones amidst can be observed in the basic RHS-MCM-41 structure. However with tungsten incorporation degree of crystallinity increased which may be due to growth in crystalline WO3 phase. Quantification of total acidic sites on catalyst surface was performed using non-aqueous potentiometric titration method with n-butylamine. The very initial potential value (E0, mV) observed at the start point of titration of the non-aqueous solid suspension enabled us to classify the materials according to their acidic strength. Earlier studies [34,42] showed that this method gives comparable results as the Benesi’s method [43,44]. In present study the total acidic strength and surface site density of all the catalysts were determined (Table 2 ) using the potentiometric titration curve (Fig. S12 in SI). Fig. 5 represents quantitative distribution of acidic sites of different strength, over catalyst surface W-0 to W-20. According to Covarrubias et al. [34] the acidic sites were grouped into four categories: E>100mV (VS: very strong sites); 0<E<100mV (S: strong sites); 0>E>−100mV (W: weak sites) and E<−100mV (VW: very weak sites). The weak and very weak acidic sites were observed on all the catalysts surface whereas strong acidic sites originated significantly, after tungsten incorporation to the basic aluminosilicate support. It is expected that incremental tungsten loading would increase the quantity of strong acidic sites which was observed up to 15wt.% but reduced on 20wt.% of W loading. This observation may be explained considering the structure of WOX species formed on catalyst surface. From W-0 to W-10 acidity raises due to formation of higher number WOX species per unit surface area. However the quantity of very strong acidic (i.e. VS) sites was less up to W-10 and was highest in W-15 catalyst. Whereas for W-20 catalyst acidity is high but the VS sites are less in quantity, which may be due to formation of stable crystalline WO3 phase (as observed in wide angle XRD) rather than dispersed amorphous WOX phase. Earlier studies also reported that formation of amorphous polyoxotungstate phase showed strong acidity relative to the crystalline WO3 phase [32,33]. The UV–vis DRS spectra of tungstated RHS-MCM-41 catalysts (Fig. 6 A) shows absorption bands originated from ligand to metal charge-transfer (O2p-W5d) [32]. The required energy for the same, depends primarily upon the coordination structure and phase crystallinity of W(VI) species which are controlled by the surface W coverage, its interaction with support and preparation procedure [8]. The bands around 220nm and 260nm refers to monotungstate tetrahedral W(VI) and polytungstate octahedral W(VI) species respectively [8,32]. The spectral bands indicate formation of two dimensional polyoxotungstate species over the mesoporous support [8,32]. As W content increases the absorption band intensity also increases up to W-15 but then reduces for W-20 which indicates better dispersion of polyoxotungstate species in W-15 rather than W-20 where crystalline WO3 phase is formed as supported by the wide angle XRD measurement (Fig. 2). Fig. 6B presents the variation of absorption edge energy (Eg) along with variation of tungsten loading in studied catalysts. It reveals that with increasing W loading on mesoporous support Eg value increases from 3.95eV (W-5) to 3.96eV (W-15) but with W-20 it decreases to 3.84eV. The Eg values lying near 4.0eV also supports formation polyoxotungstate species [45,46] Thus UV–vis DRS study along with XRD and acidity measurement revealed that, formation of efficiently dispersed two dimensional polyoxotungstate species with its highest number density contributed for the strongest acidic sites generation in W-15 relative to the others. The Raman spectra of W-5 to W-20 catalysts are presented in Fig. 7 . From the spectra it is evident that in W-20 sharp bands at 793, 703 and 258cm−1 represents the formation of WO3 crystalline phase. However for pure WO3 these bands arise around 805, 715 and 270cm−1. Here the band shift (12cm−1) may be due to interaction with the support. The bands at 984 and 874cm−1 may be due to ν s(WO) and ν as(WO) stretching respectively and the bands at 500–700 and 190–330cm−1 may be for W-O-W mode of vibration in polyoxotungstate species formed on W-15 catalyst. The bands at 767 and 317cm−1 may be assigned to the asymmetric stretch of WOW bridging bonds and OWO bending mode of WOX species. The band at 1019cm−1 may arise from stretching mode of terminal WO bond surface WO5/WO6 polyoxotungstate species. Although a partial WO3 crystalline phase formation is observable in W-15 and very small proportion in W-10 catalyst but most portion of dispersed tungsten species are incorporated in formation of two dimensional polyoxotungstate structure in case of W-15 catalyst [45–47]. 3.2 Methanolysis of soybean oil Initial study was done at 140°C with varying methanol to oil molar ratio, catalyst dose and reaction time for evaluating their effects on reaction. In present study, set of experimental conditions were derived from Central Composite Design. Catalyst dose, methanol to oil molar ratio and reaction time were varied from 1.6 to 18.5wt.% of oil, 13 to 47:1 and 1.5 to 15h respectively using RSM as optimization tool. The parity plot, presented in Fig. S13 (SI), showed an R2 value of 0.9 which indicates a very close agreement between the experimental and model predicted values. The surface plots in Fig. 8 A–C presents the interactive effect of catalyst dose, methanol ratio and reaction time on FAME yield. It is evident that with increasing catalyst dose and reaction time FAME yield enhanced sharply up to a critical value of 15wt.% catalyst dose and 10.5h reaction time. Afterward as the reaction time was prolonged it resulted lowering of FAME yield may be due to reversibility of reaction. Similar effect was also observed by Omar and Amin [14]. However further rise of catalyst dose did not result in significant improvement of FAME yield. On the other hand interaction effect between methanol to oil molar ratio and reaction time (Fig. 8B) indicates that irrespective of methanol to oil molar ratio FAME yield increased with reaction time generating a maximum at 10.5h followed by slight declination at later stage. This is similar to the earlier interaction plot (Fig. 8A). Similarly at fixed reaction time with increase in methanol to oil molar ratio up to 40, FAME yield increased with subsequent reduction afterward may be due to methanol overloading thereby dilution effect of the active catalytic sites [6,48]. The simultaneous effect of catalyst dose and methanol to oil molar in Fig. 8C explains that both the parameters effect positively on FAME production up to a critical value but thereafter resulting minor reduction in yield. Thus the overall optimization process landed to the optimum reaction condition of 15wt.% catalyst dose, 40 methanol to oil molar ratio and 10.5h reaction time at 140°C to yield 89.9% FAME. The contribution of uncatalyzed reaction resulted 28% of oil conversion with 12% of FAME yield only. Methanolysis of soybean oil were carried out using all the catalysts from W-0 to W-20 under optimum condition to find out the most active one. The result is presented in Fig. S14 (SI). It is clear from that with W-0 catalyst FAME yield was very low (40.2%) which increased with increasing W incorporation up to W-15 (89.9%) but with W-20 FAME yield reduced to 82.7%. Hence, W-15 was found to be the most active catalyst. Reaction kinetics was investigated at three different studied temperatures 120°C, 140°C and 160°C. Pseudo first and second order rate equations were applied to explain the observed FAME production kinetics up to the optimum reaction time, 10.5h. In methanolysis of soybean oil; as methanol was used in high proportion, its concentration may be considered to be constant throughout the reaction. Thus the reaction should follow pseudo first order kinetic model. The same was observed in the kinetic analysis of results. The rate Eqs. ((1) & (2)) applied are as follows [49] (1) k R = − 1 t b ln ( a − x a ) = − 1 t b ln ( 1 − x a ) (2) ln ( 1 − x a ) = − k R b t = − k t Where, k=pseudo first order rate constant, a=concentration of TG, b=concentration of methanol, x/a is the fractional FAME yield at time t. Thus plotting ln(1-x/a) with time t, a straight line with negative slope was obtained where the pseudo first order rate constant can be found from the slope. Fig. S15 (SI) represents the pseudo first order kinetic plot for methanolysis of soybean oil at 140°C. The values of rate constants up to the optimum reaction time at studied temperatures are listed below in Table 3 . The activation energy (Ea) for the studied reaction using Arrhenius Eq. (3) was found to be 42.7kJmol−1. The Arrhenius plot for three different temperatures 120, 140 and 160°C are presented in Fig. S16 (SI). (3) k = A exp ( − E a R T ) The range of activation energy reveals, whether a catalyzed process is diffusion limited (Ea lies between 10–15kJmol−1) or it is truly governed by chemical step (Ea >25kJmol−1) where the catalyst exhibits its maximum activity [50] From the value of activation energy in present study it can be inferred that this catalytic reaction is governed by chemical step and not diffusion limited. The kinetics of oleic acid conversion in mixture with soybean oil is presented in Fig. S17 (SI). It also followed a pseudo 1st order kinetics giving the rate constant value of 0.2055h−1. The variations of rate constants with varying catalyst dose and methanol/oil molar ratio are presented in Figs. S18 and S19 (SI) respectively. It is evident that, with increasing the catalyst dose and methanol ratio the value of rate constants also increased reaching a maximum at the optimum reaction condition but then declined. Reusability of solid catalyst in biodiesel production is an indispensable aspect as it can reduce the production cost and environmental pollution by avoiding waste generation. The most active catalyst (W-15) of this studied series was tested for reusability. After each catalytic run, catalyst was separated and used for a fresh reaction. The result presented in Fig. S20 (SI) reveals that, present catalyst can be reused up to four cycles without any pre-treatment. FAME yield reduced by ∼10% from very first to fourth cycle of reuse. This activity reduction may be due to blockage of active sites by adsorption of reaction intermediates thereby reduction in their effective number. However washing with hexane followed by drying and calcination regenerated the catalyst activity almost by 95%. Leaching test of tungsten species was performed by reusing the same methanol obtained from a reaction mixture for a new reaction without any catalyst, which gives almost same oil conversion as obtained in uncatalyzed reaction. After fifth catalytic run, when the W-15 catalyst was tested for tungsten quantification by EDS analysis; result showed that only very little amount of tungsten was leached from the catalyst and observed tungsten concentration in fresh and regenerated catalyst was 14.9 and 14.6% respectively (Table S5 in SI). One of the most important aspects of using solid acid catalyst for biodiesel production is its capability to withstand the presence of high FFAs in TG feedstock and simultaneously catalyzing esterification and transesterification process. Catalysts activity was tested with soybean oil mixed with oleic acid to various proportions for methanolysis. Oleic acid concentration was varied from 1 to 10° (as defined by g of oleic acid per 100g of soybean oil). The W-15 catalyst was found to be equally active even in the acidity degree of 10 resulting ∼86% FAME yield. Thus it may be concluded that this class of catalyst can suitably be applied for TG feedstocks with high FFA content. 3.3 Proposed reaction mechanism In present study, W-15 catalyst was observed to show strongest acidity compared to others. UV–vis DRS study and Raman spectroscopy support the formation of well dispersed two-dimensional polyoxotungstate structure in W-15 catalyst which is responsible for generation of VS sites and likewise it showed highest reactivity. Whereas in W-20 the dispersed WOX species transformed to stable crystalline WO3 phase thereby reducing the number density of VS sites compared to W-15. The proposed mechanism involving the strong acidic sites participating in methanolysis of triglyceride may be presented by Scheme 1 . Like the homogeneous catalyzed process the Brönsted/Lewis acidic centers on solid catalyst surface acts for activation of carbonyl carbon atom of TG molecule by developing a partial electron deficiency on it due to slight electron shift towards the acidic centers via H-bonding or Lewis acid-base type interaction with carbonyl oxygen atom. Thus in view of the homogeneous acid catalyzed mechanism, the overall heterogeneous process for FAME production from TG may be divided into four steps. Step ‘A’ proceeds with creating partial electron deficiency on the carbonyl carbon atom thereby making it more susceptible for nucleophilic attack by methanol. Step ‘B’ involves nucleophilic attack by methanol molecule on carbonyl carbon of TG which further proceeds via formation of a tetrahedral transition state (T.S.) to result FAME and DG (diglyceride) through steps ‘C’ & ‘D’. On further repetition of these aforementioned steps (A to D), one mole TG finally produce three moles of FAME along with one mole glycerol. Tungsten incorporation on RHS-MCM-41 originates strong surface acidity as observed in acidity measurement. Number density and strength of these acidic sites are significantly controlled by WOX domain size, the nature of tungsten coordination, structure and crystallinity of WOX phase. Increase in tungsten content as well as calcination temperature results in increased crystallinity of the WOX phase, which in turn reduces the strength of acidic sites. On the contrary Low temperature calcination favors formation of amorphous WOX phase which exhibits more acidic nature [32,33]. Electron delocalization and coordinative unsaturation in the small WOX cluster raises Brönsted and Lewis acidic centers over catalyst surface. With increase in W surface coverage formation of amorphous polyoxotungstate phase was observed in W-15 catalyst. But on further increment presence of crystalline WO3 phase was identified rather than polyoxotungstate phase. This in turn reflected in the acidic site distribution showing higher number density of VS sites in W-15 catalyst relative to W-20 catalyst. Thus, formation of small polyoxotungstate cluster favors genesis of strong acidic sites thereby enhancing catalytic activity also. Comparative performances of different acidic catalysts used in biodiesel production either from free fatty acids or from vegetable oils are summarized in Table 4 . It is evident that for most of the solid acidic catalysts the reaction is slower as compared to solid base catalysts [12]. The reason may be understood considering the reaction pathway, structure of active catalytic sites and attacking nucleophile. Earlier studies reported that acid catalyzed transesterification proceeds via activation of ester carbonyl groups of TG molecules by interaction with acidic sites thereby enhancing electrophilicity of carbonyl carbon which now becomes susceptible to nucleophilic attack by alcohol. Whereas the base catalyzed process initiates with the formation of alkoxide ion acting as a strong nucleophile towards ester carbonyl carbon of TG molecule. Thus acid catalyzed transesterification process is slower and requires higher reaction temperature as compared to base catalyzed one [12]. Different solid acid catalyst −as they have their own advantages over solid base catalysts- when considered it can be easily observed that they require high reaction temperature, alcohol ratio and catalyst dose when long chain TGs are used as feedstock in biodiesel production. Whereas in case of FFA esterification, appreciable conversion was achieved, even at mild reaction conditions like low temperature, alcohol ratio and catalyst dose. WO3/ZrO2, a well known superacidic catalyst showed good activity in palmitic acid esterification with methanol [33] at relatively low temperature but required high catalyst dose and methanol ratio. When WO3/ZrO2 catalyst was used for methanolysis of waste acid oil (dark oil) with high FFA content [26], it required comparatively high temperature (150°C) and high catalyst dose to achieve 96% FFA conversion in 2h, at methanol to oil ratio 9:1. Thus from Table 4 it is evident that different solid supports when functionalized with WO3, SnO2, SO3H, TPA or any other acidic groups they commonly require high temperature, methanol ratio and catalyst dose when used in transesterification of TGs rather than esterification of FFAs. Besides, mostly these catalysts were synthesized using expensive precursors whereas in present study the catalyst was synthesized using biogenic silica obtained from an agro-waste rice husk ash. Hence, it can be said that the catalyst studied here is of very low cost but gives a good FAME yield under comparable reaction condition with good recyclability. 4 Conclusions Two dimensionally dispersed polymeric WOX species supported on mesoporous RHS-MCM-41 catalyst was successfully synthesized via incipient wetness impregnation method. Catalyst characterization with SEM, TEM, SAXRD and nitrogen adsorption-desorption BET-BJH method helped to study the surface morphology, crystalline nature of as well as porosity of the mesoporous catalyst. WAXRD, Raman spectroscopy and UV–vis DRS study enabled to understand the structural insight of aluminosilicate support and surface WOX phase formed over it. Acidity determination with n-butylamine helped to quantify the distribution of strong and weak acidic sites over catalyst surface. Observations revealed that functionalization of RHS-MCM-41with WOX groups enhances the surface acidity of catalysts significantly compared to the basic Al-MCM-41 framework. Extent of W incorporation from 5 to 20% leads to formation of various polymeric WOX species on RHS-MCM-41 surface. Increasing loading of W is associated with increased crystallinity of surface WOX phase which in turn converted into stable crystalline WO3 phase in W-20 catalyst. But distribution of very strong acidic sites are more in W-15 catalyst where WOX species transformed to amorphous polyoxotungstate phase showing the strongest acidic nature among the studied catalyst (W-0 to W-20). When the catalytic activity was tested for methanolysis of soybean oil, there W-15 catalyst exhibited the maximum activity with 89.9% FAME yield among them. This catalyst responded equally well when externally oleic acid was added to soybean oil, representing low grade TG feedstock. The RSM method optimized the highest 89.9% FAME yield at 140°C within 10.5h with methanol to oil molar ratio 40 for the catalyst (W-15) with a dose of 15wt.%. Using different degree of acidity (i.e. FFA), it was observed that present catalyst can simultaneously give 86% FAME yield and almost 83.6% of FFA conversion. The catalyst was found to be successfully reused up to five cycles without any regeneration. Thus, it can be concluded that well dispersed polyoxotungstate incorporated RHS-MCM-41 may serve as an economic and efficient catalyst for biodiesel production from high and low grade oils eliminating the disadvantages faced with conventional homogeneous catalyst. coredata.dc:description: A superacidic mesoporous catalyst WOX/RHS-MCM-41 was synthesized using high purity biogenic silica extracted from an agro-waste, rice husk ash. Catalyst acidity was enhanced by dispersion of surface WOX groups on mesoporous support and was used for methanolysis of soybean oil and free fatty acid. Catalyst activity was found to depend upon the structure of WOX species formed over catalyst surface. Characterization with XRD, SEM, TEM, UV–vis DRS, Raman spectroscopy and acidity determination revealed that formation of highly dispersed amorphous polyoxotungstate phase on the catalyst surface developed with a specific tungsten loading and originated strong acidic sites showing high activity. Kinetic analysis revealed that pseudo-first order kinetics was followed up to the optimum reaction time with an activation energy 42.7kJmol−1. Catalyst showed high activity giving ∼90% FAME yield and reusability for multiple cycles without regeneration. The high catalytic activity was retained even in presence of free fatty acid also.
coredata.dc:title: Polyoxometalate based mesoporous acidic catalyst from biogenic silica for vegetable oil methanolysis: Structure activity relationship study
